Award.AwardTitle: Using the Higgs Boson to Probe and Test the Standard Model at ATLAS
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide support for a group with one PI, a postdoc and two graduate students to work on the ATLAS experiment at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN, a particle physics laboratory in Geneva, Switzerland. The LHC is a large, complex machine that accelerates protons to unprecedented energies, allowing for discovery of elementary particles more massive than any yet observed. One of the LHC's primary objectives was to find the Higgs Boson, the last particle in the historically successful "Standard Model" (SM) that accounts for much of the interactions of particles forming the visible matter in the universe. Though doubts linger, many physicists believe the new particle is the Higgs Boson long predicted by the SM. Nevertheless, more careful measurements of its rarer decay modes need to be made. Surprises are possible, and could result from effects beyond the SM that are yet to be discovered. This project will focus on efforts to do this by looking at events that pair a Higgs boson with another particle. Searches for extremely rare processes as will be sought in this effort require the use of sophisticated software and computing tools, modern machine learning techniques, data mining and the use of complex statistical tool kits. These skills are useful not only in particle physics and other STEM fields, but also outside of academia and the research world as companies, non-profits and governmental organizations across the country look to the large data sets newly available from social media and computing databases to provide better products and more useful services to customers and
citizens.

The proposal supports work to be done in Run2. This is about to begin at the full energy potential of the LHC of 13 TeV, almost twice that in Run1 and twice the energy ever studied with precision before. This group will focus on events with a Higgs Boson accompanied by either a t quark, a t-tbar pair or another Higgs. The PI has expertise in such analyses in Run1 that may allow him some advantage in dealing with different conditions likely to occur in Run2. The group will be working on the ATLAS fast tracker (FTK) that will allow new triggers that might allow the events of interest to be found more efficiently.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A major program of study for proton-proton collisions at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) is probing and testing the Standard Model (SM) of particle physics using the Higgs boson. Such exploration can take many forms, including tests of the Higgs boson coupling (interaction strength) to both itself as well as to the other fundamental objects in the SM. The major physics components of this grant were to use the ATLAS experiment at the LHC to study the Higgs boson coupling to the top quark, the largest of its interactions in the SM, and also to search for the Higgs boson's self-interactions, which provide direct information about electroweak symmetry breaking (which explains why electricity+magnetism are long-range forces but the weak force that powers the sun is not). In addition, the grant provided resources to help commission, install and integrate the Fast TracKer (FTK) system for ATLAS. FTK is a trigger upgrade that will provide the trajectory, location and parameters of charged objects emerging from the interaction region to help ATLAS decide which collisions are worthy of recording and which can safely be rejected.

The PI helped lead the ATLAS experiment in its first Run 2 paper that searched for tth production in the bb final state, an analysis that contributed to the ATLAS observation of the tth process, which connects the top quark to the Higgs boson. The tth(bb) signature is particularly complex, with numerous final-state objects in the detector. The analysis required a detailed understanding of numerous backgrounds as well as several multivariate techniques to separate signal and background. The PI and his postdoc and student also helped ATLAS publish its first Run 2 search for Higgs boson pair production in the yybb final state. Though the process has not been observed, limits were set on its production cross section and on the potential range of values for the Higgs boson self-coupling, as well as on new resonances that could decay to hh final states. The student and postdoc are preparing for the follow-up analysis with more data by adding new topologies (VBF) and new analysis tools (MVA techniques), and the postdoc is now leading ATLAS hh efforts. She was also key to help ATLAS publish its first hh combination paper, which combined limits from multiple final states. Finally, the PI, his graduate students and postdoc were key members of the team commissioning and integrating FTK with the ATLAS detector, including work in online software, testing and monitoring of the system, as well as the software used to simulate the system and prepare its inputs for data-taking.
